title: 110_hr392
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" and it involves the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and each of the territories. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection for the redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and the territories in 2009. Quarter dollar coins issued in 2009 will have designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and territories, with flexibility in inscription placement. Quarter dollar coins issued in 2009 will have designs representing the District of Columbia and territories, with flexibility in inscription placement. The design on the reverse side of each quarter dollar issued in 2009 will represent the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, or American territories. The reverse side of quarter dollars issued in 2009 will feature designs emblematic of the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, selected by the Secretary after consultation. The Secretary will select 6 designs for quarter dollars representing the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands after consultation with relevant officials. After consultation with relevant officials, the designs for quarter dollars representing the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be reviewed by the Commission of Fine Arts and the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The Secretary may designate territory for quarter dollar designs, reviewed by the Commission of Fine Arts and Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee, with a selection process at the discretion of the Secretary. Participation is at the Secretary's discretion. Designs for quarter dollars may be submitted through the design selection and approval process developed by the Secretary. Participation may include District or territorial officials, artists, engravers, and members of the public. Standards for designs are important. The Secretary may include participation by District or territorial officials, artists, engravers, and the general public in the design selection process for quarter dollars. The Secretary must ensure that only dignified designs are chosen for minting. The Secretary must ensure that only dignified designs are chosen for minting quarter dollars, prohibiting frivolous or inappropriate designs. Additionally, no head and shoulders portrait or bust of any person, living or dead, and no portrait of a living person may be included in the design. The Secretary must ensure dignified designs for minted quarter dollars, prohibiting inappropriate designs. No portraits of living or deceased individuals allowed in the design. All coins minted under this subsection are considered numismatic items. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars of each design. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars of each design selected under this subsection, considering them as numismatic items. The coins can be minted in uncirculated and proof qualities, and the Secretary may also mint and issue silver coins. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars of each design selected under this subsection in uncirculated and proof qualities, as well as silver coins with a content of 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. Coins honoring the District of Columbia will be minted under this subsection. The Secretary will mint quarter dollars with 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper to honor the District of Columbia and territories in 2009 in a specific order. The Secretary will mint quarter dollars with 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper to honor the District of Columbia and territories in 2009 in a specific order, with each territory receiving coins in equal sequential intervals. The legislation applies to the District of Columbia or any territory becoming a state or gaining independence before the 10-year period ends. The legislation applies to territories like Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, and the US Virgin Islands if they become independent or cease to be territories before quarter dollars are minted with their designs. The legislation applies to territories like Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, US Virgin Islands, and Northern Mariana Islands for minting quarter dollars with their designs. The legislation was passed by the House of Representatives on January 23, 2007, as confirmed by Karen L. Haas, the Clerk.
